As a bird flies, there is always low pressure on the upper surface of a bird’s wing - if not, it wouldn’t be flying. The lifting of the feathers in this video is the result of return flow from the trailing edge. The bird wing at this point is near a stall because the birds are trying to remain aloft at very low speed. In normal flight, a bird’s wing will obviously have low pressure on the upper surface, but you don’t see feathers lifting then, do you? No.

I know I'm way late in my response here but I'm relatively new to your channel.  Anyway,  I have a different take on what's happening to the Macaw's feathers on the back of their wings when they are being lifted up.  You said that's being caused by the relative low pressure area on top of the wings.  I don't think that's actually what's happening in this case.  The bird, at that point in the video, was slowing down to land.  As such, it was flying with it's wings at a relatively high angle of attack and it's wings were actually stalling around the shoulder area which is the only area where we see the feathers being lifted up.  As the wing's angle of attack (AOA) exceeds a certain limit, the airflow over the top of the wing separates and burbles off, causing a loss of lift.  There are videos of this on airplane wings where they use small strips of yarn taped to the top of the wing.  As long as the airflow is smooth, the wing is generating useable lift and the strips of yarn are all lined up and harmonious.  Once the wing stalls, the airflow separates, burbles off and the strips of yarn all go flapping around in just about every direction possible.  I think that's what happening to the feathers on the back of those birds.  You'll note that it's only happening at the shoulder area.  The birds are flapping hard as they slow down and all the lift they are making is being produced on the outer 40 to 50% of the wing which is still moving with sufficient speed because of the flapping motion and you'll note, no burbling feathers even though there's definitely lift being produced out there.  If you look at the earlier point in this video where the birds are flying level, in more of a cruise configuration, you'll note that all the feathers on the back of the birds are flat and smooth on both the down and up beats of the wings because they have good airspeed and the airflow over the top of the full span of the their wings and body is smooth and controlled, generating lift.

There's an even more interesting component to bird wings that you didn't mention.  Some researchers in the UK showed how the wing tips cutting into the wind on the down stroke create a standing vortex that's positioned along the high lift area on the top of their wing.  So, not only are they getting lift from pushing air down and the differential pressure of air flowing over the wing, but they are creating a stationary vacuum vortex to pull them up.

Hey Destin.  Something you may have missed in your bird flight observations.  Notice how the primaries twist on the downstroke, so that the upper surface faces partly forward.  Air moving past these primaries as they stroke down creates lift, but a vector of this lift is directed forward.  This is more important in maintaining forward motion than any backward directed push of air in the downstroke is.

As a child I used to watch the birds come out to play every fall when the storms would hit in the pacific northwest. Winds would gust up to 50 mph and the birds would "fly" against the wind flapping full speed and not make any ground, then tilt their wings and catch enough air to shoot them backwards. They would repeat the process as if playing a game. At about the same time in life, I would have my arm out the window and use my hand to plane the wind aerodynamically, and by twisting my arm just a bit, my hand would catch more air and at a certain point, catapult my hand backwards. This was fun.
I imagine if you watch the birds long enough you will see that some are more gifted "athletes" than others. You'll even see different body types. Hey Destin, I doubt you'll read this but anyway. Birds have different kinds of feathers for different parts of their bodies, this mechanic you've talked about is why feathers are often asymmetrical. They're lined up so that the broader part of the inside feather is resting under the shorter part of the outside feather. When pressure applies from below it acts like a valve and seals, then when pressure applies from above the feather rotates about the quill and allows air through like you see in the footage. I suppose it's kind of like Venetian blinds but they supported slightly to one side instead of the middle. When wind blows from one direction they get caught on each other and block it but when it blows from the opposite direction they can freely rotate and let it through.

Hope anyone that reads this finds it mildly interesting, sadly I don't quite have Destin's prowess for explanation.

on the upstroke, when the feathers separate into a 'venetian blind' effect, each individual feather, which is clearly air-foiled, now becomes a mini wing and is lift producing. The whole wing acts as a single lifting air-foil on the down stroke and the upstroke is still producing lift but from each feather individually- look closely and you'll see that's how the birds body continues on its level path with out oscillating up and down in response to changing lift - because the lift is constant through the whole cycle. In the slot between feathers the airflow leaving the underside of a feather accelerates over the top of the next feather, more airspeed equals more lift. In some slow flight situations that 'backward' move you mention comes into play as well. And ...

Robert Meyer; Wolfram Hage et al at the German Aerospace Centre and University of Berlin have done wonderful research into the phenomenon of feathers popping up on the back of the wing at high angles of attack. This process stops the stalling airflow separating near the trailing edge from flowing forward to kill the lift on the forward part of the airfoil/wing, where the main lift is concentrated - and it's entirely automatic. Perfect high angle of attack stall prevention. Look for their paper "Separation Control by Self-Activated Movable Flaps" for experiments with this on glider wings.
Great observation, many things are hidden to us because they are too slow or to fast.  But we have tools today that (if you have access) can lead you to what is really going on, or to more questions.

One more thing is happening than you observed: The Macaw's feathers were lifting due to de-lamination of the airflow over his wing. This is because he was ready to land on the cliff and was actually stalling part of his wing to reduce lift and airspeed. Just as on a human airfoil, the wing doesn't stall all at once; that would produce a fall or spin. Birds don't like that, either!  Their wings begin to stall at the root, where that won't interfere with their control of flight... just as on a Piper or an FA-18!

One aspect of bird feather design that fascinates me is that the feathers that have to function with the quill perpendicular to the flow, such as the primaries, are asymmetrical. This is essential for sustained flight, since a symmetrical feather in this position would be unstable and would flutter. As dinosaurs transitioned to birds, this was a crucial step in achieving sustained flight. Dinosaur birds had symmetrical flight feathers, so we know they could only fly in short bursts.

You did use pull incorrectly in this video when describing what was happening above the parrots wing. Those feathers are being PUSHED up by a flow of air from a high pressure to a low pressure area.

Humming birds can get propulsion both upward and forward on the backward stroke, the parrot you observe is doing the same thing but to a lesser degree.

He meant there's no pull in fluids. Fluids can only be pushed from high pressure to low pressure. Pulling comes from atomic bonds, with atoms attracting their neighbor. This attraction in fluids is weak, and so cannot push anything.
Search Wolly Roller Birmingham Roller for a wrinkle in flight behavior for you to critically think about

I believe balleand is referring specifically to the idea of low pressure "pulling". It would be more accurate to say that the high pressure is pulling, just like touching a cold object makes heat flow out of you rather than coldness flowing in. As for the feathers: they are sticking up because the wing accelerating downwards is pulling them straight, just like the rope you mentioned is pulled straight if you tug on it. Also, air currents may be pushing them up some. Low pressure cannot pull.

You did forget about the wave part of the wing's motion. To create even upward (and forward) thrust, the bird has to move its wings in a wave pattern where the top of an upstroke the front of the wings are at the top, and at downstroke the bird has to have his front part of the wings slightly lower to thrust in forward direction. One can mimic this motion by moving their arms so that it looks like their arms are floating on top of waves.Also, hummingbirds do create downward thrust on backstroke.

The classic example of changing resistance is rowing in a boat. You wouldn't wave your paddle side to side or up and down and expect to go anywhere. You rotate the oar to reduce or increase the resistance as needed. You naturally start following an elliptic shape because you want to cut through the less resistance faster.

So when those feathers on the top of the wing are getting ruffled, that's the bird stalling the root chord of the wing. A circulation is set up that is pushing the air at the surface of the wing from the trailing edge to the leading edge.  On my hang glider I have two tufts of yarn (semi-calibrated) mounted near the root chord just forward of the trailing edge.  I can look at their shadow (on the fabric wing) in slow flight to see if the root chord stall is partial or complete.

I mean, I never realized that before either, but doesn't everybody (humans) do something similar when they're swimming? Cup your hands and stretch out your limbs when pushing forward and when you're resetting for another push, you open your fingers and let your limbs closer to you. Right? It *is* so simple.

i don't think any vertical take-off momentum is generated on that back swing, haha. the wing looks "break" in half to reduce resistance on the back swing. probably easier to do this with a break midwing vs. using the whole wing due to bird anatomy: (1) it requires the wing to stretch further from default position for same effect, and (2) there is less rotational moment of inertia to rotate two objects vs. one object of a combined size.

Most birds create lift by causing air to move over the airfoil shape of the wings like an airplane or helicopter. When a humming bird hovers, it is flying more like an insect; it creates lift by creating low pressure on the up side of the wing (alternately the top and bottom) by generating a vortex on that side.  This creates a nearly equal amount of lift on both forward and backward strokes.  It is a very efficient way to create lift, but doesn't scale up well to large animals or to aircraft.
